text: Alice Pollitt Deschaine [born Margaret Pollitt] (July 19, 1929 – March 15, 2016) was an infielder who played from through in the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League. Listed at , 150 lb., she batted and threw right- handed.W.C. Madden. All-American Girls Professional Baseball League Record Book. McFarland & Company, 2000; A native of Lansing, Michigan, Margaret Pollitt was born to John and Mary (née Miller) Pollitt. She grew up in a home where sport was considered of vital importance. Her father, who had been a professional soccer player in England before coming to the United States, was also an avid baseball fanatic and motivated her to play the game at a very early age.Susan Johnson. When Women Played Hardball. Seal Press, 1994; A two- time All-Star, Pollitt was discovered by an AAGPBL scout while she was playing in her hometown and entered the league in 1947. She played all seven of her AAGPBL seasons with the Rockford Peaches, helping them win three championships pennants by combining a sharp defense and provided stability through the middle of the batting order.Women in Baseball: The Forgotten History – Gai Ingham Berlage, Charley Gerard. Greenwood Publishing Group, 1994; Pollitt started at shortstop in her rookie season, then anchored third base for six years as part of a solid and durable Rockford infield that included Dorothy Kamenshek at first base, Mildred Deegan at second and Dorothy Harrell at shortstop.1947 Rockford Peaches, aagpbl.org; accessed March 19, 2016. Her most productive season came in 1951, when she collected a .299 batting average and tied with Fort Wayne Daisies' Betty Foss and teammate Eleanor Callow for the most home runs (four). Pollitt also ranked fourth in total bases (158), fifth in hits (121) and runs (88), seventh in average, while tying for second in triples with Kamenshek (9) behind Rockford Peaches' Eleanor Callow (10). In addition, she gained her first selection for the All-Star Team.All-American Girls Professional Baseball League Record Book1951 AAGPBL All-Star Team, aagpbl.org; accessed March 19, 2016. In 1952, Pollitt batted .270 and stole 35 bases, being selected to the All-Star Team as a reserve infielder. She then posted career-numbers with a .315 average and 14 doubles in 1953, her last year in the league.1952 AAGPBL All-Star Team, aagpbl.org; accessed March 19, 2016. Pollitt was also one of two hundred players to attend the first AAGPBL spring training outside the United States, which was held in 1947 in Cuba at the Gran Stadium de La Habana.When Women Played HardballAll-American Girls Professional Baseball League History , aagpbl.org; accessed March 19, 2016. ==Personal life== After marrying in 1951 to Glenmore Deschaine (who died in 1991), the couple had two children, a son and a daughter.Margaret Deschaine obituary, legacy.com; accessed March 19, 2016. In November 1988, Alice along with her former teammates and opponents, received their long overdue recognition, when the Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum in Cooperstown, New York dedicated a permanent display to the All American Girls Professional Baseball League.AAGPBL official website Alice died on March 15, 2016 at Bay Bluffs, Harbor Springs, Michigan.
